Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Pleistocene/Holocene Climate Reconstruction from a Pamir High Resolution Deep Ice-Core
Award.AbstractNarration:
Central Asia is highly dependent on glacier meltwater for its water resources. Its high mountains hold great volumes of glacial ice, with seasonal snow melt supplying up to 80% of the region's fresh water needs. However, since the 1960s, central Asia has lost over 14% of its glacier covered area and ~18% of its ice volume. Changes in glacially-fed hydrologic systems impact water availability and biodiversity in these regions. However, these observations cover only a fraction of the climate history of this region. Ice cores from glaciers in the high Himalayas preserve records of millennia of climate changes. Understanding the natural variability recorded in such records is of critical importance for interpreting the vulnerability of the region to modern and future climate change.

This project will recover a surface-to-bedrock ice core from the Pamir, Tajikistan, which will be used to develop detailed records of climate changes in central Asia during the Holocene and beyond. The results will be used to reconstruct the dynamics and rates of moderate, abrupt, and threshold changes in climate in Central Asia. Specifically, the research team will generate annually-resolved, multivariate geochemical records from the ice cores (including stable isotopes, trace elements, major ions, and dust particles), recover pollen and other biological materials, and compare the results with ice core and other paleo records from the interior of Asia. Chronological control will be established with a variety of techniques (layer counting, radiocarbon, beryllium-10, lead-210, and tritium). The project involves scientific collaboratio with international research partners from Germany and Japan as well as from local government departments in Tajikistan. Graduate students from two US institutions would be involved in the international activities, which will include both field expeditions to collect the ice cores and follow up sampling and collaboration visits.

This project is jointly supported by the Paleoclimate Program of the Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences, the EPSCoR program, and the Division of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Central Asia (CA) is one of the most arid regions on Earth, and is particularly sensitive to changes in seasonal moisture delivery. For the last two millennia, climate proxy records show that moisture delivery to CA has varied widely. The Pamir Mountain Range in CA is home to dozens of glaciers that serve as critical repositories for precipitation, feeding meltwater to multiple major river systems, including the Amu-Darya, the most melt water-dependent major river system on Earth. Roughly 80% of Central Asia’s surface water is sourced from snow and ice melt in the Pamir Mountains feeding water to the ~72 million inhabitants of the region. As a contribution to the understanding of water resources and climate in Central Asia researchers involved in this project:

(1)  Summarized and synthesized past climate records for CA covering the last 2000 years demonstrating that there are relatively few past climate records available and that these are either short (200-400 years) or low resolution. For modern climate we find that the season during which precipitation begins and when temperatures in the glacierized highlands is cold enough for precipitation to accumulate, on glaciers and snowfields, which is normally March-April-May, is getting shorter. Small shifts in the seasonal timing or patterns of temperature and precipitation threaten this delicate balance. We document +1oC of warming in the glaciated highlands of CA over the last decade, compared to the previous 27 years of satellite data, which itself represents an already warming baseline, compared to preceding decades. Over the same period, we find a decrease in annual precipitation during the critical May cold/wet season of 2-5cm/a. Taken together, these patterns are consistent with significant CA glacier retreat.

(2)  Utilized our innovative in-house, publicly available (2000-3000 hits per day), climate reanalysis software (Climate Reanalyzer) to investigate modern climate change. Utilized and enhanced innovative new technology developed in our WM Keck Laser Ice facility to examine at ultra-high resolution, orders of magnitude beyond current state-of-the-art resolution, changes in seasonality during natural analogs for warm and cold conditions. This technology allowed us to develop the longest annually resolved ice core record from CA (~1600 years) despite the highly-compressed state of the record.

Dating assignment of the ice core was accomplished by a combination of standard sampling techniques (~100 samples/meter) and utilization of our WM Keck Laser Ice facility LA-ICP-MS sampling (~10,000 samples/meter) that extends annual layer counting and seasonal differentiation in highly compressed ice. Dating was supported by use of a standard ice compaction model and the identification of previously known volcanic events. Most notable of the volcanic events was the 1257/1258 CE mega-eruption of the Salamas supervolcano that is recorded in many ice cores around the world and is in the Pamir ice core coincident with the largest isotope depletion (associated with volcanic induced cooling) in the entire 1600 year-long record.  In addition, Pamir ice core age dating is also constrained by another anomalous event, the lead drop associated with the Black Death (1347-1351) discussed further in (3) below.

Fe, Ca, and Mg signals in ice cores allow atmospheric circulation fingerprinting (source and circulation intensity). Sub-seasonal scale changes in the relative intensity and coherence of these dust source elements, identified using our LA-ICP-MS analysis, is investigated in the Pamir ice core for sections representing the pre-MWP (Medieval Warm Period, during the MWP, and at the onset of the LIA (Little Ice Age), illuminating regional and local scale variations in atmospheric circulation.

Naturally warm and cold climate periods in CA history serve as precursors for potential conditions in future decades. The geographically-small region within which the high alpine glaciers of CA currently exist is expected to continue to shrink even if summer-time northerly flow increases, associated with Arctic warming and opening of Arctic ocean moistiue sources, because the optimal season for snow preseevation is earlier in the year. CA glacier mass balance warrants very careful tracking, since these glaciers provide critical water resources to human and non-human communities alike.

(3) Extended the spatial range of the Black Death epidemic, that triggered the shut-down of mining and smelting throughout Europe and no doubt into Asia, which means that this decrease to near nil levels in the atmosphere extended at least over the distance between the original ice core record defining the Pb drop (Colle Gnifetti, Switzerland) and the Pamir ice core site, a distance of ~5000 km. This finding further substantiates the realization that natural levels of lead in the atmosphere are close to nil and that health standards for lead are significantly higher than natural levels. Further, the Black Death lead level drop provides yet another absolute dating marker for ice cores.
